metadata.case_name: Appellant (Owner of Premises No. 10/3, Swarnamoyee Road) v. Howrah Municipality

facts.text: The appellant is the owner of the premises No. 10/3, Swarnamoyee Road, Howrah.
The appellant encroached upon an area of 57 x 3 of the road-side land of the Howrah Municipality.
A notice was served on the appellant to remove the encroachment, the terms of which required removal within thirty days from the date of service.

The notice was headed under s. 299 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923, requiring removal of encroachment caused by a compound wall measuring 57-0 x 3-0 upon Swarnamoyee Road attached to premises No. 10/3.
The appellant failed to carry out the terms of the notice within the specified time.
Prosecution instituted before the Municipal Magistrate, Second Class, Howrah, in Case No. 1407C/1952.
Municipal Magistrate convicted appellant under s. 488/299 of the Act and sentenced to fine of Rs. 75 on 8th September, 1953.
On appeal (Criminal Appeal No. 185 of 1953), Sessions Judge, Howrah acquitted appellant on 14th November, 1953, on ground of limitation under s. 534 of the Act.

Municipality filed Criminal Revision No. 1113 of 1954 in Calcutta High Court; Division Bench (J.P. Mitter and S.K. Sen JJ.) set aside acquittal on 2nd February, 1955? Wait, no: directed re-hearing after bringing official documents on record.
On re-hearing, Additional Sessions Judge confirmed conviction and sentence, dismissed appeal.
Appellant filed revision in High Court; P.N. Mukherjee J. on 2nd February, 1955, affirmed conviction under s. 488/300, reduced sentence to Rs. 50.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) of Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.
The offending structure was a compound wall and not something which was a part and parcel of the main building.
Official documents proved that complaint was instituted within time, not barred by s. 534.

legal_issues.text: Whether the alteration of conviction from s. 488/299 to s. 488/300 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 was legal, without prejudice to the appellant.
Whether the notice served under s. 299 was a lawful requisition under s. 488(1)(c) read with s. 300.
Whether the prosecution was barred by limitation under s. 534 of the Act.
Whether the appellant suffered substantial prejudice due to alteration of section.

petitioner_arguments.text: Alteration of conviction from s. 299 to s. 300 r/w s. 488 was not possible in law as notice under s. 299 to remove compound wall unattached to building could not be lawful requisition under s. 488(1)(c).
Notice headed under s. 299 makes conviction under s. 300 illegal as requisition not lawfully made.
Prosecution launched beyond three months limitation under s. 534.
Substantial prejudice caused as under s. 299 might claim compensation.

respondent_arguments.text: Complaint instituted in time as per official documents.
Facts establish offence under s. 300 r/w s. 488; no prejudice as accused aware of accusation.

court_reasoning.text: Alteration from s. 299 to s. 300 r/w s. 488 was not alteration in substance but to section more properly applicable to facts found; similar to Begu case where conviction altered under CrPC ss. 236, 237.
court_reasoning.key_observation: A man may be convicted of an offence, although there has been no charge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made.

court_reasoning.text: Substance and not form of notice to be regarded; effective part required removal of encroachment by compound wall, appellant fully aware and failed to comply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It is the substance and not the form of the notice that has to be regarded.

court_reasoning.text: Additional evidence proves complaint lodged in time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The additional evidence placed before the Court puts the matter beyond all reasonable doubt that the complaint had been lodged in time.

court_reasoning.text: No prejudice shown; appellant invited High Court interference, fine reduced, no deprivation of defence opportunity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It has not been shown that the appellant had, in any way, been prejudiced in the trial of the case as a result of the alteration in the section.

holdings.text: Conviction under s. 488/300 upheld; alteration legal as facts same and evidence establishes offence.
Notice constituted lawful requisition under s. 488(1)(c) r/w s. 300 despite heading under s. 299.

precedents_cited.relevance: Authorizes alteration of conviction to offence made out by evidence under CrPC ss. 236, 237 even without charge under that section.

statutes_cited.name: Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs encroachment removal notices, offences for non-compliance, limitation, and trial by Municipal Magistrate; conviction under s. 488(1)(c) r/w s. 300 for failing to comply with requisition to remove compound wall encroachment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Permits conviction for offence established by evidence even if no charge framed under that section.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed as there is no merit; conviction under s. 488/300 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 and sentence of fine Rs. 50 upheld.

key_quotes.text: "A man may be convicted of an offence, although there has been no charge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle allowing alteration of conviction based on Begu precedent.

key_quotes.text: "It is the substance and not the form of the notice that has to be regarded."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument on notice heading; validates requisition.

key_quotes.text: It seems to me to be arguable... that a notice under section 299 to remove a compound wall unattached to any building could not be a notice lawfully given... within the meaning of section 488(1)(c).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Chief Justice's observation granting certificate, but ultimately rejected by SC.
